185996675.review:
I recommend using some kind of image sharpening for this game, you should be golden after that.

Don't really care what other F.E.A.R. fans say about this game. I've played through all of them now. What you have here is not a Monolith developed game, what you have is a Monolith infected game, yes somehow their DNA still made it in despite it not being made by them, couple that with John Carpenters artistic consultation and what you end up with is a masterpiece in its own right. The combat is outrageously tight and responsive, some of the finest you will ever experience. I really enjoy Paxtons grinning comments and interjections while playing through as Point Man, it sounds raw gritty and feigns with great delight Monoliths classic tongue in cheek sense of humor and smarm. 

The cutscenes really tie in this game, giving it coherence and continuity. If you allow it in, it is a really immersive high speed freight train screaming to a smoldering hell. I love how the creative direction of this game just flat out didn't give a damn how sick it came off to the player base or viewership. It's unapologetic concerning that, which I find refreshing in today's gambit of garbage, gravy train riding, money grabbing, people pleasing, drop down to knees, and vacuum off some politically polite snowflake that demands you be a proper gentleman.

So what do I ultimately think about F.E.A.R 3? I think you catch the drift of my sentiments already. 

Being able to go back and play as Paxton is just the icing on the cake. The game's cover system is optional, I found myself only partially using it, ultimately it's there if you want to use it but is easily fully omitted. The sound design and music are top notch, although being  slightly glitchy on rare occasion. The sound department in this game just flat out owns and exerts its dominance compared to a lot of stuff out there.

185769376.review:
This is probably my second favorite game in the series. They finally gave up on pretending to be "scary" and "tactical" and just went all in on the world and fun action gameplay, adding coop and wrapping up the Fear series with more fun over the top action. It's very well made, and did what the last two games and their DLCs couldn't, cut the crap and let me shoot way more stuff while actually letting me tag along with another player in coop when they kept adding multiplayers that barely made sense since every other game had you mostly alone or only being with your enemies and friends behind bulletproof glass.

They made the visuals even better, much higher poly models, better textures, big environments, forests with tons of foliage, great shadows and lighting, and they added these hellish skyboxes which especially look awesome. Most areas are bigger or have much more detail and way better lighting and especially density, being full of physics objects and debris that reacts to you and fettel. 

They've finally gotten away from mostly just drab hallways or back alleys and cramped streets, and also made the mechs from the last game even better by having two of them going on a huge rampage while you go over a highway and kill everything that moves. They also made the army and monsters the most wild and cool out of all of these games. The Electric heavy soldier bosses being my favorite. The cutscenes are also improved, having some excellent presentation and clearly a much higher budget, even getting John Carpenter to help make them. 

And it shows, the presentation is a huge step up from every game prior in almost every way, the only problem I had was the ending. The ending comes out of nowhere. It made absolutely no sense and made me wonder if something was cut. They end the game by killing Becket from Fear 2, and Fettel and Pointman are suddenly in a cabin in the woods fighting Alma's Dad after being swept up by a tidal wave of blood. Like it hard cuts to Pointman and Fettel as kids, then the game has you go into the cabin without any transition or explanation as to how you got there, making me think a level was cut or something went wrong.

Looking into it, it seems like a ton of content was just completely axed, even in older development videos, there were entirely different versions of the script where you played as female characters that didn't match with what we got here at all, but I would've been interested in maybe seeing in a Fear 4. Like a drop in, drop out fps horror coop game, like fear meets a beat em up, maybe with more customizable squads, and vehicle sections. They were onto something here, and the ending lacking a proper transition to the final boss making no sense was extremely jarring. 

But that issue aside, the story and game was an improvement on Fear 2, I liked it, the multiple endings added some replay value, and it was a fun, if not short spooky action coop game.

I also liked the new multiplayer modes they added, Fucking RUN!!! being one of my new favorites, where you and your friends have to book it asap before a wall of death and destruction kills you, all while trying to fight enemy soldiers ahead of you who've set up random checkpoints and bases. It's hectic and fun. And the random generation makes you think on the fly.

There's also a cod zombies type mode where you defend against soldiers and monsters, but the online multiplayer was fun too, and I had a lot of fun with this game. They were pushing Fear to doing some really fun new stuff, and it's a shame they haven't made any more, with successor games like Trepang2 opting to take notes off the first game, which was so hilariously bad, cheap, and not scary that I'm surprised by how much people like such a mediocre low resolution shovelware game. 

The only scary thing about that game ironically was that it was so dirty and dark that you couldn't see 3 feet in front of you while trying to shoot the literally copy pasted bad guys who came out on an assembly line. Meanwhile this game is awesome, and so is Fear 2. Don't let pretentious Youtubers and second rate indie devs making a bad mockup of a bad mockup horror game tell you otherwise. Particles don't make a game fun, gameplay does. And this game nails it.

Meanwhile, this concludes my review. Thanks for reading. Take care!

185531567.review:
There are two ways to look at this game.
 
If you are a fan, played or watched the first and second game and you are looking to play this one then you must prepare your expectations, big time. If, weather you have or haven't played the first two game but you are looking just for something different from the F.E.A.R franchise and want a decent, good looking FPS with a good story then, you may not find it here as well. 

I tried to find the good things first. Some scenarios really catch the dark vibe with gory elements and tense missions but this feeling felt short very quickly in a already short, compact campaign. The jump scares no longer feel jumpy, the scares are gone when you get past the fact that you know they are coming. This game was from an era of "grey shooters" where there was plenty of them. Call of Duty, Medal of Honor, Spec Ops the Line, Gears of War and so on. But those game had their own theme going on and stayed mostly true and honest to that. In FEAR 3 it feels like there were no previous games. This game has no right to have F.E.A.R in its name. They could have made this one but with another title and keep the focus on what made the other two games more memorable for a proper follow-up.

The game lost its identity. We became clueless of what the game is trying to be. 

It's a fast-paced FPS? It's a co-op game to play like you were playing Left 4 Dead fighting hordes of enemies in waves? Is it a horror game? It's a war game? Why I'm I going against soldiers with a huge mecha-tank shooting missiles and destroying helicopters? Why can't I choose when to walk and when to run, all the time? There's no need to force walk to go for a tense moment when minutes later we'll be going gun-blazing against countless of soldiers. It has pacing issues. Perhaps if you want a mindless first person shooter game to play with a friend in waves it could be worth your time but by now I'm sure you already found that game in most recent times with better gameplay to offer.

F.E.A.R 3 was building their own style but instead they choose inspiration from other games and lost what made F.E.A.R great in the first place. Here's hoping they go back to its roots instead of trying to be another clone of other successful games.

185492937.review:
'A Co-Op Twist on Fear'
F.E.A.R. 3 takes the series in a new direction, blending its iconic action and horror elements with co-op gameplay and a heavier focus on fast-paced combat. 
While it strays from the tense atmosphere of the earlier entries, it still offers a fun and unique experience.
The highlight is the co-op mode, where players can choose between Point Man and his ghostly brother, Paxton Fettel. 
Each character has distinct playstyles, Point Man excels in traditional gunplay with slow-motion abilities, while Fettel uses psychic powers for creative and chaotic combat. 
This dynamic keeps the gameplay fresh, especially in multiplayer.
The scares take a backseat to the action, with a few eerie moments scattered throughout. 
Alma’s presence is still felt, but the horror is less psychological and more about the grotesque visuals and set pieces. 
The campaign story is serviceable, focusing on the brothers' troubled relationship and Alma’s twisted legacy.
While F.E.A.R. 3 may disappoint those expecting the same dread-filled atmosphere as the first game, it compensates with tight gunplay, engaging co-op mechanics, and a satisfying dose of supernatural chaos. 
It’s not the scariest entry in the series, but it’s a fun ride for fans of action-oriented shooters.

Man merkt hier leider das es zu einer Zeit rausgekommen ist wo viele First-Person Shooter immer mehr auf Action Action und noch mehr Action gesetzt haben. Der Horror der die Serie ausgezeichnet hat ist hier leider sehr zurückgeschraubt worden. Wo es im ersten Teil eine sehr gute Mischung zwischen Shooter Passagen und Horror Passagen gegeben hat und der zweite Teil es auch noch gut geklappt hat , ist es hier leider zu einem 90 % Action und nur 10& Horror Spiel verkommen. Außerdem hatte ich hier leider nur die geschnittene Deutsche Version die die Gewalteffekte komplett rausgenommen haben und somit noch mehr von  der schon sehr kleinen Atmosphäre geraubt haben. Wo ich leider aber meinen Spaß hatte war der KOOP Modus. Auch wenn das den Horror komplett raus nimmt, macht das Spiel mit einem Freund richtig viel Spaß. Besonders da die beiden Brüder von Alma unterschiedliche Fähigkeiten haben und immer in Konkurrenz stehen der bessere Sohn von Mama Alma zu sein und am Ende die Punkte der vielen Herausforderung zusammen gezählt und der bessere Sohn bekommt das Ende, somit kommt man in diesem Spiel gleich zwei Enden. Die Story ist nur solala und eher Mittel zum Zweck um die Geschichte von Alma zu beenden. Der Multiplayer habe ich nur Kurz angetestet und fand die Modis dort nicht so gut. Ich glaube auch nicht das der MP noch geht und ob die die Server abgeschaltet haben.

So zum Ende würde ich der Deutschen Version keine Empfehlung aussprechen weil einfach die Gewalteffekte ein bisschen die Atmosphäre gehalten hätten. F.E.A.R 3 é pra mim uma decepção, isso não significa necessariamente que seja um jogo ruim, mas de forma alguma consegue chegar perto da qualidade do segundo jogo, e comparado ao primeiro dá até pena dos desenvolvedores.

Falando sobre a jogabilidade no combate, vi uns caras falando que esse jogo é mais desafiador em comparação ao segundo, NÃO É. Na verdade o combate aqui é bem massante. 

Essa mecânica de cover onde você aperta um botão e o personagem fixa em alguma estrutura é horrível em FPS e eu vou explicar porque: Este tipo de cover só funciona em jogos de terceira pessoa, por que assim você consegue se proteger, ver o cenário melhor e ter mais liberdade pra tomar decisões no combate. Quando aplicada aqui num jogo de primeira pessoa o personagem se esconde e vc não consegue ver quase nada!!! os inimigos mudam de posição, jogam granada pelas suas costas, se aproximam do seu cover e vc nem vê o que está acontecendo, além dos cenários aqui serem bem mal planejados pra vc combater dessa forma, o que torna a experiência ainda mais massante... O combate em F.E.A.R 3 é burocrático! se você quer um combate mais desafiador no F.E.A.R 2, é só colocar a dificuldade no nível mais alto. 

Nos dois primeiros jogos vc se diverte, está sempre pensando no próximo combate, nas variedades de inimigos, nas armas, você tem cenários mais abrangentes com mais opções de abordagens, enfim...

Sobre a história do jogo também decaiu muito: nos dois primeiros jogos da franquia, a história é contada durante o jogo à medida que vc vai avançando por meio dos cenários, nos áudios, nos arquivos que você encontra, nas conversas entre os personagens etc. Aqui no F.E.A.R 3 eles preferiram fazer isso na maior parte nos interlúdios entre as fases, então funciona assim: você começa a fase e atravessa um cenário matando uns caras e as vezes uns monstros, no fim da fase aparece o Fettel (irmão do protagonista) pra narrar pra você mais um pedaço da história. Cara, isso é um jeito tão preguiçoso de desenvolver um roteiro, é vergonhoso, é ridículo! no primeiro e segundo jogo vc sente uma vibe investigativa como se você mesmo fosse descobrindo a verdade aos poucos, se um cara fica narrando a história vc não se sente tão engajado a prosseguir.

É muito triste que essa franquia tenha uma conclusão tão meia boca, os caras foram preguiçosos até no design do protagonista mano!!! ... mas fica aí o aviso, se for comprar espere uma boa promoção e guarde bem na memória os jogos anteriores, pq esse aqui é uma bomba.

184285626.review: Game plays well. Still not what I wanted from the FEAR franchise, but a better offering overall than FEAR 2. The second game is needed as context for the plotline of 3, but both don't really amount to much and I feel this game may be better played just as an arcadey experience. I almost wish that's what it was intended to be, especially in the coop. The coop feels like you're playing time crisis or similar on rails shooter just with how the two playstyles force you to tackle levels, and I think it would have made an awesome experience in that setting in an arcade, but instead you play an FPS and it just is nothing standout. As a single player experience on the other hand the game comes through a lot better. There are times that feel designed for coop, namely the phase trooper guys are tough to tackle as Point Man alone, but okay just tedious as Fettel. Point Man playthrough is slow and methodical, good for seeing how the story plays out but makes you approach everything as a bit of a cover shooter. Fettel playthrough on the other hand just feels made to blow through everthing as efficiently as possible. Funnily enough, even though the frachise is intended to make you feel like you're in an action movie, the Fettel playthrough was the first time I felt that experience throughout my time in any of the games. The story doesn't amount to anything, the gameplay is whatever, the sounds and visuals are pretty meh. Really only worth a play if you want an arcadey coop experience to ignore the story to set in the FEAR universe.

183547324.review:
FEAR 3 is super underrated. Some of that hate it gets from its initial release is still relevant to a degree, this game is for sure a Call of Duty clone where the devs sacrificed the campaign for graphics and multiplayer while ripping off COD mechanics (i.e. aiming down the sights of your gun and regenerating health). What a lot of people don't know is COD4, the original Modern Warfare, seems to have taken a lot from the original FEAR, and FEAR came out before COD4 did; so honestly, I'd say FEAR is simply borrowing back from the copy cat. Even though critics originally panned things such as aiming down your sights and regenerating health, I think these fit perfect in FEAR because FEAR is a grounded modern FPS game (as the original FEAR was excluding all the sci-fi paranormal elements. This game can be HARD as fuck. But if you liked playing the original FEAR on the toughest difficulty, you'll probably welcome the challenge.  I had a lot of fun in this game. Honestly, I wish WB games would've kept up this franchise. FEAR definitely needs a remaster/remake/reimagining--and not that BULLSH*T Ubisoft did with Thief 4. 

The ending, especially being able to choose to be good or evil, was super dope; the story was really interesting (although, I think its a shame a lot of stuff from the original FEAR and its expansion packs were sort of forgotten and written out).  

I don't know if multiplayer works on this game. Every time I try to boot it up into practice mood, I'm either a zombie wraith thing or in this sort of COD zombies survival game without knowing really what the hell's going on. (But, on that note, if you can play this split screen on 360/PS3, for sure pick it up if you got those systems).
